intro: Eleusine indica subsp. barcinonensis, commonly known as the narrow-leaf fingergrass, is a perennial grass species native to tropical and subtropical regions. It typically grows in disturbed soils and is often found in agricultural fields and along roadsides. The plant has slender, grass-like leaves with a prominent midrib and produces small, spike-like inflorescences. Its botanical features include a fibrous root system and a tendency to spread through rhizomes. It is often considered a weed but has some traditional uses in certain cultures.
